articles.headline: Woes for ITT, a For-Profit School, Bode Worse for Its Students
articles.snippet: How bad will it be for students if ITT Educational Services, the troubled for-profit school, fails? Ask the former students of a company called Wilfred.
articles.abstract: How bad will it be for students if ITT Educational Services, the troubled for-profit school, fails? Ask the former students of a company called Wilfred.
articles.lead_paragraph: The vise appears to be tightening at the for-profit education giant ITT Educational Services. Its profits are collapsing, its stock is below $2, and last Monday the company got bad news from the Education Department in Washington, a main overseer.

articles.headline: Gawker, Filing for Bankruptcy After Hulk Hogan Suit, Is for Sale
articles.snippet: The company’s decision to sell itself came just weeks after it was revealed that the Silicon Valley billionaire Peter Thiel financially supported Mr. Hogan’s lawsuit.
articles.abstract: The company’s decision to sell itself came just weeks after it was revealed that the Silicon Valley billionaire Peter Thiel financially supported Mr. Hogan’s lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gawker Media, the irreverent company that pioneered the wry tone and take-no-prisoners approach that came to embody a certain style of web journalism, put itself up for sale on Friday in an acknowledgment that its future as an independent news organization was in doubt.

articles.headline: Apple Starts to Woo Its App Developers
articles.snippet: With growing competition from the likes of Google and Amazon, Apple appears to be working to improve its relationship with app makers.
articles.abstract: With growing competition from the likes of Google and Amazon, Apple appears to be working to improve its relationship with app makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s iPhone would be just a well-made phone without the apps that allow people to personalize it with their favorite games, news, business, social and video services. Software makers need Apple, too: They badly want to be on the devices that people carry with them everywhere, especially as traditional websites and desktop computers fade in importance.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Vigilantes Patrol Parts of Europe Where Few Migrants Set Foot
articles.snippet: In countries like Slovakia and Hungary, vigilante groups are portraying a menacing incursion of asylum seekers to build support for their xenophobic agendas.
articles.abstract: In countries like Slovakia and Hungary, vigilante groups are portraying a menacing incursion of asylum seekers to build support for their xenophobic agendas.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — The People’s Party-Our Slovakia, after months of stirring up fears about foreigners and Muslim migrants, decided to take action: This spring, the group’s leader proudly stood in front of the main railway station in Zvolen, Slovakia, and announced that a new group of volunteers would begin patrolling passenger trains to keep the “decent citizens” of Slovakia safe from criminals and minorities.
articles.byline: By Miroslava Germanova, Boryana Dzhambazova and Helene Bienvenu

articles.headline: Drug Maker’s Former Employees Accused of Shady Dealings With Doctors
articles.snippet: Two former employees of Insys are accused of paying doctors to participate in “sham” educational programs in exchange for prescribing the powerful painkiller fentanyl.
articles.abstract: Two former employees of Insys are accused of paying doctors to participate in “sham” educational programs in exchange for prescribing the powerful painkiller fentanyl.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Roper, once a sales manager at Insys Therapeutics, a small pharmaceutical company, had a problem. The end of the quarter was near, and for the first time, Insys was in danger of missing sales goals for its only product, a spray called Subsys that contains the powerful painkiller fentanyl.

articles.headline: The Chinese Hackers in the Back Office
articles.snippet: A dusty old computer in a mom-and-pop Wisconsin welding shop is giving a digital security firm a window into the operations of Chinese hackers.
articles.abstract: A dusty old computer in a mom-and-pop Wisconsin welding shop is giving a digital security firm a window into the operations of Chinese hackers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVILLE, Wis. — Drive past the dairy farms, cornfields and horse pastures here and you will eventually arrive at Cate Machine & Welding, a small-town business run by Gene and Lori Cate and their sons. For 46 years, the Cates have welded many things — fertilizer tanks, jet-fighter parts, cheese molds, even a farmer’s broken glasses.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley Suburbs, Calls to Limit the Soaring Rents
articles.snippet: Bay Area towns that tech made rich as considering rent control, an urban tactic, to save a middle class squeezed by years of punishing rent increases.
articles.abstract: Bay Area towns that tech made rich as considering rent control, an urban tactic, to save a middle class squeezed by years of punishing rent increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — After years of punishing rent increases, activists across Silicon Valley and the San Francisco Bay Area are pushing a spate of rent control proposals, driven by outrage over soaring housing prices and fears that the growing income gap is turning middle-class families into an endangered species. Those campaigns, if successful, would lead to the largest expansion of tenant laws since the 1970s.

articles.headline: While Young Britons Favor Staying in E.U., They Aren’t Big on Voting
articles.snippet: Holding the attention of young voters — and getting them to turn out on June 23 for a referendum on whether Britain should stay in the European Union — is a challenge.
articles.abstract: Holding the attention of young voters — and getting them to turn out on June 23 for a referendum on whether Britain should stay in the European Union — is a challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On June 23, tens of thousands of young Britons will be gathered at the Glastonbury music festival, whose headliners include Coldplay, Muse and Adele. Others will be avidly following the European Soccer Championship in France or biting their nails in anticipation of the next episode of hit teenage soap “Hollyoaks.”

articles.headline: China Tries to Redistribute Education to the Poor, Igniting Class Conflict
articles.snippet: A plan to expand higher education to students from impoverished regions, at the expense of the urban middle class, has set off an intense backlash.
articles.abstract: A plan to expand higher education to students from impoverished regions, at the expense of the urban middle class, has set off an intense backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Cheng Nan has spent years trying to ensure that her 16-year-old daughter gets into a college near their home in Nanjing, an affluent city in eastern China. She wakes her at 5:30 a.m. to study math and Chinese poetry and packs her schedule so tightly that she has only 20 days of summer vacation.

articles.headline: To Understand Clinton’s Moment, Consider That It Came 32 Years After Ferraro’s
articles.snippet: A look back to when Geraldine A. Ferraro was on the Democratic ticket in 1984 can tell a lot about how the country has changed, and how it has not.
articles.abstract: A look back to when Geraldine A. Ferraro was on the Democratic ticket in 1984 can tell a lot about how the country has changed, and how it has not.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scenes blend like images from a kaleidoscope. A woman, blond, jubilant in a white dress, shown magnified on a convention center screen in San Francisco. It is Geraldine A. Ferraro in 1984 accepting the Democratic nomination that made her the first woman in the nation to be tapped by a major party to run for vice president.

articles.headline: Orlando Gunman Attacks Gay Nightclub, Leaving 50 Dead
articles.snippet: Praising ISIS, the gunman, identified as Omar Mateen, opened fire in what emerged as the worst mass shooting in United States history. The massacre early Sunday also left 53 wounded.
articles.abstract: Praising ISIS, the gunman, identified as Omar Mateen, opened fire in what emerged as the worst mass shooting in United States history. The massacre early Sunday also left 53 wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — A man who called 911 to proclaim allegiance to the Islamic State terrorist group, and who had been investigated in the past for possible terrorist ties, stormed a gay nightclub here Sunday morning, wielding an assault rifle and a pistol, and carried out the worst mass shooting in United States history, leaving 50 people dead and 53 wounded.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Cable Industry Mobilizes Lobbying Army to Block F.C.C. Moves
articles.snippet: Giants like Comcast, AT&T and Verizon oppose plans to limit broadband providers’ ability to share users’ data and to open the market for set-top boxes.
articles.abstract: Giants like Comcast, AT&T and Verizon oppose plans to limit broadband providers’ ability to share users’ data and to open the market for set-top boxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In recent weeks, staff members for Bobby Rush, a Democratic congressman from Illinois, have asked fellow lawmakers to sign a letter opposing a Federal Communications Commission proposal to limit how broadband providers can share users’ personal data.

articles.headline: Last Call at Pulse Nightclub, and Then Shots Rang Out
articles.snippet: The gunfire did not let up. As rounds were fired, people dropped, some in panic, some because they were wounded, some because they were dead.
articles.abstract: The gunfire did not let up. As rounds were fired, people dropped, some in panic, some because they were wounded, some because they were dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was nearing last call.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Managers Work to Stanch Loss of Investors
articles.snippet: As funds continue to falter, some managers are negotiating with investors to retain them, and offering newcomers terms that were once just for longtime clients.
articles.abstract: As funds continue to falter, some managers are negotiating with investors to retain them, and offering newcomers terms that were once just for longtime clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hedge fund titans once ran their firms like elite private clubs, picking who made it past the velvet rope and how much they would pay for access to supercharged performance.

articles.headline: Gawker’s General Counsel Takes On a Leadership Role
articles.snippet: Heather Dietrick, president and general counsel of Gawker Media, has taken a prominent role in dealing with a legal judgment, bankruptcy and sale.
articles.abstract: Heather Dietrick, president and general counsel of Gawker Media, has taken a prominent role in dealing with a legal judgment, bankruptcy and sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heather Dietrick, Gawker Media’s president and general counsel, has always been close to her 90-year-old grandfather, a prisoner of war during World War II who, she said, “has taught me a lot about fielding a lot of situations.”

articles.headline: Bill Simmons Prepares to Stand Up to Sports Incorporated
articles.snippet: The influential sportswriter and commentator, who was fired from ESPN after making incendiary remarks concerning the National Football League, begins a new show on HBO on June 22.
articles.abstract: The influential sportswriter and commentator, who was fired from ESPN after making incendiary remarks concerning the National Football League, begins a new show on HBO on June 22.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Corporate media giants always want what’s cool and edgy until what’s cool and edgy threatens the status quo that keeps the billions flooding in.

articles.headline: Was Orlando Shooter Really Acting for ISIS? For ISIS, It’s All the Same
articles.snippet: The terror group has blurred the line between operations planned and carried out by its core fighters and those carried out by its sympathizers.
articles.abstract: The terror group has blurred the line between operations planned and carried out by its core fighters and those carried out by its sympathizers.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The revelation that the 29-year-old man who opened fire on Sunday in a gay nightclub had dedicated the killing to the Islamic State has prompted a now-familiar question: Was the killer truly acting under orders from the Islamic State, or just seeking publicity and the group’s approval for a personal act of hate?

articles.headline: Orlando Attack Roils Gay Community, Painfully Accustomed to Violence
articles.snippet: Gay Americans, and those working to advance their rights, spent Sunday grappling with the implications of the mass shooting at a gay nightclub.
articles.abstract: Gay Americans, and those working to advance their rights, spent Sunday grappling with the implications of the mass shooting at a gay nightclub.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 3 o’clock in the morning on Sunday, Benjamin Newbern, a gay rights activist in northern Alabama, arrived home from a gay pride dance party he had organized, glanced at his cellphone and spotted an unsettling social media post: “Prayers for our brothers and sisters at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando.”

articles.headline: Omar Mateen: From Early Promise to F.B.I. Surveillance
articles.snippet: The Orlando gunman’s life once seemed to be on a successful track, but he became the subject of investigations and allegations of abuse.
articles.abstract: The Orlando gunman’s life once seemed to be on a successful track, but he became the subject of investigations and allegations of abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT PIERCE, Fla. — Omar Mateen’s life seemed to be on a successful trajectory a decade before he carried out one of the worst cases of mass murder in American history.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Jack Healy and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Walgreens Cuts Ties to Blood-Testing Company Theranos
articles.snippet: In another blow to Theranos, the embattled blood-testing company, Walgreens said it would no longer offer its laboratory services in 40 of its stores.
articles.abstract: In another blow to Theranos, the embattled blood-testing company, Walgreens said it would no longer offer its laboratory services in 40 of its stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walgreens said on Sunday that it was terminating its relationship with Theranos, dealing a severe blow to the embattled blood-testing company. Walgreens said it would immediately close all 40 of the Theranos testing centers in its Arizona drugstores, the source of most of Theranos’s customers.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Microsoft Buys LinkedIn for $26.2 Billion, Reasserting Its Muscle
articles.snippet: The companies said that Microsoft would pay $196 a share to acquire LinkedIn, the business social network site.
articles.abstract: The companies said that Microsoft would pay $196 a share to acquire LinkedIn, the business social network site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft has made its most ambitious move in years to reassert itself in a technology market it once dominated.

articles.headline: Blaming Muslims After Attack, Donald Trump Tosses Pluralism Aside
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump appeared to broaden his proposed ban on Muslim immigrants, while Hillary Clinton accused him of damaging efforts to defeat terrorism.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump appeared to broaden his proposed ban on Muslim immigrants, while Hillary Clinton accused him of damaging efforts to defeat terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump left little doubt on Monday that he intends to run on the same proposals on immigration and terrorism that animated his primary campaign, using his first speech after the massacre in Orlando, Fla., to propose sweeping measures against Muslims that pay little heed to American traditions of pluralism.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
